usage.param: The argument on which a is to be created.

macro.para:
The primary purpose of this macro is to bind certain elements of a such that the parsing mechanism can parse past those elements. Technically, just about any sequence of preprocessing tokens is a . Because of the limitations of the preprocessor, however, the cannot parse past certain types of preprocessing tokens. For example, in the following code:
(+ _1, x)
The cannot reach the _1, and consequently cannot replace it. This macro may be used in such situations to bind preprocessing tokens.
((+) _1, x) // + x

Another purpose of this macro is to create that contain open commas. One of the rules of a is that it must be passable as a single argument, so an expression such as
a, b
cannot be a . This macro allows for the creation of such expressions.
(a, b)

Finally, the last purpose of this macro is to define on macro names. For an arbitrary macro MACRO, this is commonly accomplished in one of two ways. The first is...
#define MACRO_ (MACRO)
The second is...
#define MACRO_ (MACRO_ID)()
The second form requires an indirection macro, MACRO_ID, that expands to MACRO when invoked with nullary parentheses. This indirection acts as a buffer that allows the resulting to pass through MACRO without the identifier MACRO becoming disabled.

macro.abstract: The macro is used to define and undefine the .

usage.param: The value that determines whether the should be defined or undefined. Valid values are 0 and 1.

macro.para: If bit expands to 1, the (e.g. _0, _1, etc.) are defined by the library. Otherwise, they are undefined.

It is important that the definitions of the only exist temporarily because they are unprefixed macro definitions that will interfere with any other use of those identifiers. Therefore, for every use of that enables the , there should be a matching use of that disables them. The library cannot enforce this directly, but the mechanism may be used to enforce it, or the longhand form may be used instead.

Names that begin with an underscore are reserved for the implementation in file scope (C) or the global namespace (C++). Consequently, if a standard header is included while the are defined, the result is undefined behavior. As a general rule, no "normal" headers should be included while the are defined.
